questions.question:
Box P has 2 red balls and 3 blue balls and box Q has 3 balls and 1 blue ball. A ball is selected as follows: (i) select a box (ii) choose a ball from the selected box such that each ball in the box is equally likely to be chosen. The probabilities of selecting boxes P and Q are 1/3 and 2/3 respectively. Given that a ball selected in the above process is a red ball, the probability that it came from the box P is:

(GATE CSE 2005)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider the set H of all 3 x 3 matrices of the type
\(\begin{bmatrix} a & f & e\\ 0 & b & d\\ 0&0 & c \end{bmatrix}\)
where a,b,c,d,e and f are real numbers and abc\(\neq\)0. Under the matrix multiplication operation, the set H is:

(GATE CSE 2005)
options:
C.

a semi group but not a monoid

D.

neither a group nor a semi group
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
What is the minimum number of ordered pairs of non-negative numbers that should be chosen to ensure that there are two pairs (a,b) and (c,d) in the chosen set such that
a \(\equiv\) c mod 3 and b \(\equiv\) d mod 5


(GATE CSE 2005)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Let f: B \(\rightarrow\) C and g: A \(\rightarrow\) B be two functions and let h = f\(\cdot\)g. Given that h is an onto function which one of the following is TRUE?

(GATE CSE 2005)
options:
A.

f and g should both be onto functions

B.

f should be onto but g need not to be onto

C.

g should be onto but f need not be onto

D.

both f and g need to be onto
questions.correct_answer:
B.

f should be onto but g need not to be onto
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Let R and S be any two equivalence relations on a non-empty set A. Which one of the following statements is TRUE?

(GATE CSE 2005)
options:
A.

\(R\cup S,R\cap S\) are both equivalence relations.

D.

Neither \(R\cup S\) nor \(R\cap S\) is an equivalence relation.
